 A lot of those economic theories they are working under they are jsut making up as they go along. Most of the others are incomplete adaptations of old, proven theories. The Laffer curve, which actually predated laffer by about 1000 years is a good example. BAsically the theory there is that there is a point of equilibrium where increased taxation decreases government revenue because the high tax level chokes off the economy. Obviously under the theory of taxable income elasticity (the proper name for the laffer curve) if taxes are so high as to stifle the economy, reducing them will lead to economic growth.
 
 Sadly Reagan read that and jsut saw "tax reductions lead to economic growth", which he parroted to the american people. Sadly many of them still don't realize that there are conditions to the "tax reduction/economic growth" paradigm.
 
 I don't have a problem with the application of sound economic theory. The problem always seems to come when they try to apply poorly understood economic theory, or just make up their own as they go. 
 
 There is no accepted economic theory that says you can live in constant deficit and it will not come back and bite you on the butt later. That is another "half theory". The actually theory is that during times of rapid economic expansion, deficit spending does not hurt you because the dividends from the economic growth will allow you to easily repay that debt. Somehow this has been translated to "deficits don't matter". Stupidity stacked on top of stupidity.
 
 What people do not seem to realize is that most economic theories are not as complicated as they have been led to believe. For the most part, if it will not work for your checking account, it probably won't work anywhere else.

 There are 2 parts to economic theory. There is the "what happens" portion, which is the simple part. Then there is the "why it happens". The second part is the part that gets complex with opposing theories. The "why" portion is pretty much just mental masterbation anyway, so for all practical purposes you can ignore it.
 
 The "what" is important and is typically well established. IF you consistently spend more than you make, you will eventually go broke. That is pretty simple and anybody who has ever held $1 in their hand and lusted after something that cost $1.25 should understand it. Where things get tricky is when people try to interject the results fo their mental masturbation in the "why" category to the "what". Then you get all kinds of idiotic explanations for why the "what" is going to be different this time when, in fact, the "what" is a constant. It does not actually change.
